description: From dialectal dize (“to put tow on a distaff”), from Middle English *disen, from Old English *disan, *disian, from *dise, *disen (“bunch of flax on a distaff”), from Proto-Germanic *disanō (“distaff”), of unknown origin, equivalent to dize +‎ -en. Cognate with Saterland Frisian Diezene (“bundle of flax, distaff”), Middle Low German dise, disene (“distaff”).

verbs.description: dizen (third-person singular simple present dizens, present participle dizening, simple past and past participle dizened)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To dress with flax for spinning.
(transitive) To dress with clothes; attire; deck; bedizen.
(transitive, UK dialectal) To dress showily; adorn; dress out.
